transcript:
Patient: I find that I start the thought record with good intentions, but then I get stuck on the evidence for and against the negative thought. I start to doubt myself and question whether I'm being objective or just trying to make myself feel better. It's like I'm arguing with myself in my head, and it becomes overwhelming.

Therapist: It's common to experience self-doubt and uncertainty when challenging long-held negative thoughts and beliefs. The process of examining evidence for and against these thoughts can feel unfamiliar and uncomfortable at first. Let's break down the steps of the thought record and see if we can identify any specific sticking points or areas where you tend to get stuck.

Patient: Okay, that sounds helpful. I think I start to struggle when I'm trying to come up with evidence against the negative thought. I find it easier to list evidence that supports the thought, but then I have trouble coming up with counterarguments.

Therapist: That's a great observation. It's often easier for us to find evidence that supports our negative thoughts because they're so familiar and automatic. Challenging these thoughts requires us to step outside of our usual patterns of thinking and consider alternative perspectives. One strategy that can be helpful is to imagine what you might say to a close friend or loved one who expressed a similar negative thought about themselves. How might you respond to them? What evidence would you point out to help them see the situation differently?

Patient: That's an interesting approach. I think I would try to remind them of their strengths and past successes. I might point out specific examples of times when they handled a similar situation well or when the negative thought wasn't true.

Therapist: Exactly! You can apply that same approach to challenging your own negative thoughts. When you're struggling to come up with evidence against a negative thought, try to take a step back and consider what you would say to someone else in your situation. This can help you access a more compassionate and balanced perspective.

Patient: I like that idea. It's like being my own best friend or advocate.

Therapist: Absolutely! Another strategy is to consider whether you might be engaging in any cognitive distortions when evaluating the evidence for and against your negative thoughts. Cognitive distortions are common thinking patterns that can skew our perception of reality and contribute to negative emotions. Some examples include all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and discounting the positive. Let's look at one of your recent thought records and see if we can identify any cognitive distortions that might be at play.

Patient: Okay, let's see. I had a thought the other day that "I'm not doing enough to support my child through the college decision process." When I tried to come up with evidence against that thought, I found myself discounting the things I have been doing, like researching schools and talking through the options with them.

Therapist: It sounds like you might have been engaging in the cognitive distortion of discounting the positive. This is when we minimize or dismiss the positive aspects of a situation and focus only on the negative. In this case, you were discounting the efforts you have been making to support your child, even if they don't feel like "enough."

Patient: You're right. I have been doing my best to be supportive and involved in the process, even if it doesn't always feel like I'm doing enough.

Therapist: Recognizing and labeling cognitive distortions can help you challenge them more effectively. When you notice yourself discounting the positive, you can pause and remind yourself of the efforts you have been making, even if they feel small or insufficient in the moment. This can help you develop a more balanced and realistic perspective.

Patient: That makes sense. I think I've also been engaging in all-or-nothing thinking, where I feel like I'm either being a perfect parent or a complete failure, with no in-between.

Therapist: All-or-nothing thinking is another common cognitive distortion that can contribute to feelings of inadequacy and self-doubt. It's important to remember that parenting, like any other aspect of life, is rarely all-or-nothing. There are usually shades of gray and moments of both success and challenge. When you notice yourself falling into all-or-nothing thinking, try to look for the middle ground and acknowledge the efforts you are making, even if they're not perfect.

Patient: I appreciate you pointing out these cognitive distortions. It helps me understand why I might be getting stuck with the thought records and gives me some specific strategies to try.

Therapist: I'm glad you're finding this helpful. Remember that challenging negative thoughts and beliefs is a skill that takes practice. Be patient and compassionate with yourself as you continue to work on this. It's okay if it feels difficult or uncomfortable at times – that's a sign that you're challenging long-held patterns of thinking.

Patient: Thank you for the encouragement. I feel like I have a better understanding of why I might be struggling with the thought records and some specific strategies to try. I'm going to keep practicing and see if I can make some progress with challenging my negative thoughts.

Therapist: That's great! Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there may be ups and downs along the way. The important thing is that you keep showing up for yourself and putting in the effort to challenge these negative thoughts and beliefs. I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Patient: Thank you, I appreciate your support and guidance. It means a lot to have someone in my corner as I work through this.

Therapist: You're welcome. Before we move on, let's take a moment to summarize the key points from our discussion about thought records. We talked about the challenges you've been experiencing with coming up with evidence against negative thoughts and how this can be a common sticking point for many people. We discussed the strategy of considering what you would say to a friend or loved one in a similar situation and looked at how cognitive distortions like discounting the positive and all-or-nothing thinking might be contributing to the difficulty. We also emphasized the importance of self-compassion and patience as you continue to practice challenging negative thoughts. Does this summary capture the main points of our discussion so far?
